title: 113_s2701
content: The Act titled "Stopping Illegal Obamacare Subsidies Act" limits auto-enrollment in health plans under American Health Benefit Exchanges until inconsistencies are resolved as outlined in the Inspector General's June 2014 report. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make public the steps to clear inconsistencies in eligibility for healthcare programs within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, methods to monitor progress in resolving inconsistencies will be disclosed within the same timeframe. The Secretary will disclose methods to monitor progress in resolving inconsistencies for the Federal and State Exchanges. Premium assistance tax credits and cost-sharing programs will be suspended for 2015 until all inconsistencies related to invalid social security numbers are resolved. The Secretary will monitor progress in resolving inconsistencies for the Federal and State Exchanges. If applicant information contains inconsistencies, the Secretary will request additional information within 90 days. During the inconsistency period, an individual may be enrolled in a qualified health plan but cannot participate in the premium. During the inconsistency period, an individual enrolled in a qualified health plan cannot participate in the premium assistance credit program or reduced cost-sharing program. If additional information is not submitted, benefits will not be received. During the inconsistency period, if an applicant fails to submit requested additional information, they will be withdrawn from the premium assistance credit program and reduced cost-sharing program. The Secretary will notify the health insurance issuer, and the applicant must re-enroll in a qualified plan. During the inconsistency period, if an applicant fails to provide required information, they will be disenrolled from the premium assistance credit program. The Secretary will inform the health insurance issuer, and the applicant must re-enroll in a qualified health plan during the next open enrollment period. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "inconsistencies" refer to differences in self-attested information provided by an applicant for health plan enrollment and data received from the Federal Data Services Hub or other sources, including citizenship, income, employer-sponsored coverage, incarceration status, or other factors affecting eligibility for financial assistance programs. The term "inconsistency period" refers to a 90-day period after a notice of inconsistency is sent to an applicant for health plan enrollment, which may involve issues like citizenship, income, employer-sponsored coverage, incarceration status, or other factors affecting eligibility for financial assistance programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
